reviewText: Do you need a screen protector? A few years ago, I dropped my iPhone 3GS from about three feet, screen-down, directly onto a pointed rock. The screen protector (one of the flexible armor types) kept the screen from damage, so I vote "yes."PERFORMANCE:Very clear, nearly invisible while the phone is in use. My finger does detect an increase in friction when dragging across the screen, but no difference when tapping.APPEARANCE:During the day, this product is so clear that you do not notice it visually. However, in the dark in reflected light it is easy to see a distinct difference between the darker surface of the protector and the lighter surface of the glass around it.APPLICATION:The instructions are clear. I followed them exactly, and they worked. Peel back the first two inches, align carefully, then push forward with the applicator. It went down remarkably bubble-free. But make sure your alignment is absolutely perfect...DURABILITY:...because if one edge of this protector catches on a fingernail something, it will peel up and collect dust or finger prints, effectively ruining it. This shouldn't happen if your alignment is PERFECT, but you know how that goes. Screen protectors don't last forever, but this one peeled off rather too easily for my taste.PACKAGING:On the top front, the package says, "1 Protector" in small, lower-case text. At the bottom, it says' "CONT: 3 ITEMS" in upper-case text almost twice as tall. The 3 items are: one protector, one cleaning cloth, and one stiff cardboard applicator, which doubles as the hanging tag for the package itself. I'm sorry, but the three items claim borders on deceptive packaging, especially when a count like that is so uncommon on a package. On the back of the package, a small illustration shows 1 protector plus 1 cloth plus 1 applicator, but it does not repeat the language, "3 ARTICLES." Perhaps a committee may have been trying to make sure that you noticed that the applicator was also the hanging tag, but adding a claim for "3 ARTICLES" to the front of the package wasn't the way to do that. They should have put the illustration on the front and eliminated the "3 ARTICLES" claim. 3M does not usually make mistakes like this.RECOMMENDATION:So far, it's functional as a screen protector. I'm satisfied, but not thrilled.

reviewText: I usually use Belkin screen protectors, but I thought I would give these a go.  First off, a pet peave I have noticed many screen protectors going to is only giving you one! reviewText: The term "Screen Protector" makes you think of a thick piece of plastic that would stop the screen from shattering when you drop a rock on it. Screen protectors are actually a very thin plastic sheet which adhere to the screen. They protect the screen from light scratches if you, say, put the phone in your pocket with keys or loose change. They protect it from oil should you answer the phone after putting lotion or oil on your hands. In the process, though, they sometimes trap dust between the screen and the plastic, causing air bubbles to interfere with the appearance of the image on the screen. And sometimes they interfere with the overall image quality.In this case, 3M provides a screen cleaning microfiber cloth to use initially as well as a small piece of cardboard to be used as an applicator. Used properly, you can get the sheet on the phone without air bubbles. For this screen to be anti-glare, there's a flat coating on the sheet that degrades image quality slightly. It's not a big deal, but it's noticeable, so it becomes a glare vs image quality question. If you primarily use your phone in sunlight or under overhead lighting at work, this is a perfect solution. But if glare never bothers you, get the non-glare screen protector instead.As you apply the sheet, do so in as dust-free an area as possible. The last thing you want is for static to attract dust to the protector as you apply it. Once dust has adhered to the plastic sheet, there's no getting it off.

reviewText: I've been using smart phones since their inception, and I have NEVER liked screen protectors.  Nor have I ever liked them on my tablets, whether Windows based Tablet PC's or other things like my iPads or Kindles.  They generally serve no purpose for me, since I don't have a habit of getting scratches on devices.  Fingerprints are easy to wipe off with a microfiber cloth, and more often than not even if there are no bubbles under the film when you apply it, it seems there ends up being some at some point anyway.  So for a couple decades now, going back to even just the first old PDA's, I've avoided them.I saw this one in the Vine program and decided to give it a try more for the anti-glare properties than anything else.  I figured worst case scenario I'd pull it off.When I installed it, I had the typical frustration of some bubbles, no matter how carefully I was applying it and using a straight edge to help keep it on there.  So far, just like any other protector.  But with some judicious wrangling, I was able to get it on with only a couple bubbles out to the edges of the screen, none in the middle.  And even just using a fingernail, I was able to push them out.  And unlike most other protectors, they didn't reappear.The material is a bit thicker and stiffer than most I've used, and has a slightly rough feel to it, very different from the feel of the smooth glass.  On my Macbook Pro computer, I LOVE the glass trackpad, and even though I use palm protectors on them, I never put a protector on the trackpad, as the feel and smoothness of it is one of the things that first drew me away from PC's.  But despite that, I find I now prefer this feel on my iPhone for some reason.  It just feels better to me.  I don't use gestures on the iPhone like I do on the laptop, so the slightly rougher surface isn't a hinderance at all.The anti glare works pretty well, but it's not a total solution for glare since in some situations you just end up with a duller flat white spot rather than a glaring reflection, but that's pretty much when you position yourself using it as a mirror to an extremely bright light source, which isn't something people generally do when they're using these anyway.  So for the most part, it does help improve visibility of the device, without any notable detraction in lower light situations.  It also preserves a great wide angle viewability although you can notice some dimming at extreme angles.I use it with a case and it didn't cause any issues with getting the case on or off.  The cut is about as perfect as I've ever seen, it fits exactly as it needs to, with the cutout for the home button and one for the top by the microphone and camera (and a cut to one side, for the ambient light sensor I assume).The only downside I've seen is bits of dust or pocket lint likes to gather around the edge of the protector by the home button, nothing that a brush of a finger or blowing at it won't dislodge.All in all I'm pretty impressed with it, compared to my history with this kind of product.  I'm actually keeping it on the phone, something I hadn't really anticipated I'd end up doing.Edit December 2013 - after 6 months or so this started getting pretty awful looking around the edges.  And it's not even the edges where you'd think maybe something caught it and started to separate, but around the ear piece speaker as well.  Just dust and such that got under there and gummed up the exterior edge about a quarter inch from all the edges.  Oddly enough the bottom half of the unit was totally unaffected by this, just the top half and around the cutout for the ear speaker.  I ended up pulling it off and have my phone going commando again as far as screen protectors go.

reviewText: I'm a bit of an expert applying these types of things. I worked at the Apple Retail Store for nearly 5 years and I have probably put these types of films on at least 100 phones over the years... and I'd say these are really good films and do the job if properly applied. Let me share some tips to make this a great fit for your phone. It is crucial that dogs, cats, or any pet that bears fur or feathers be in another room and that children are not running around during the installation of the film. If you have any fans (oscillating, ceiling, etc.), make sure they are off and have stopped turning completely. Turn off the heat and/or air conditioning. Seriously - it's just for a few minutes - you need to have ZERO air movement. The air we breath is FULL of tiny, barely perceptible amounts of dust and lint hanging in near suspension in the air. As long as you stop the circulation of air, these particles begin to settle a bit. The little fibers and debris you can barely see in the air are magnified 50x the minute they get under the film. Once all air movement has settled down, it's time to prepare the phone. It should be removed from the case and cleaned thoroughly by applying an appropriate electronics cleaning fluid like iClean to a microfiber cloth. Never spray fluid onto your phone! Apply the fluid on the cloth and vigorously wipe and clean it, and examine under a bright light to make sure there are no fibers there. When you are ready to apply the film, be sure no part of your finger even grazes the edge of it - or your finger grease will be there - just enough to make the film peel back after time. Use the non-sticky backing of the film to help you line up the edges.  Apply at one edge and very slowly peel it down toward the glass to avoid air bubbles. If a bubble is visible, pull back a bit and try again. Patience is key. Also - limit your breathing to slow, measured breaths - you can exhale debris right onto the sticky surface or onto your iPhone glass. Even though the films are cut precisely for an iPhone 5, you cannot just try aligning it using the corner. During the whole process, you should be watching the hole for the home button and the ear speaker to make sure everything is lining up and that it is not askew. Once applied properly, the film is secure. Your finger won't slide quite as smoothly as it does across bare glass, but it won't leave discernable fingerprints unless you were just eating fried chicken. It takes away the glare and the annoyance of greasy finger prints occluding the view of the icons, your photos, etc. Nice product.

reviewText: The 3M Privacy Screen Protector is a thin polarized film that adheres to the front screen of your iPhone 5. There is a loss of both brightness and resolution with the greatest noticeable impact being on pictures. If you use your iPhone extensively for photos or video, you shouldn't get this protector. On the other hand, if you frequently view financial information or other private material in public, that's where you get value from this particular screen protector.Note that the protection is oriented in one direction: if the phone is held vertically, the person sitting next to you on the bus or airplane will not be able to see what you're doing. On the other hand, if you turn the phone horizontally, the person next to you will be able to see what's on the phone, albeit with reduced clarity. Similarly, if you have the phone vertically, the person standing over you on the bus while you're seated will be able to see your phone's screen. So the bottom line here, as with any polarized screen, is to be aware of the shape of your privacy oval. This is a significant improvement from a privacy perspective, but it doesn't lock out everyone who isn't directly in front of the phone.Note that the screen is somewhat thicker than your average protective screen film, so this will do a good job protecting your screen from keys, coins, or other metal objects that might be floating around in your pockets with the phone. reviewText: I've consistently found 3M to offer top of the line no compromise products . . . so I'll assume the compromises one makes with use of this privacy/screen protector are unavoidable.  My observations.Installation was easy and produced a nice bubble-free result. A micro-fiber prep cloth is provided.Privacy is afforded, as advertised, from unwanted viewing from each side, when the device is held in a vertical orientation. It does not block viewing from above - for instance from someone looking down from above you from behind, like in an airline seat situation.  Holding your iphone horizontally will allow shared viewing to the side (but not from above).  3M calls this "micro-louvre" technology . . . perhaps you can visualize the viewing "louvres" running north/south on your screen.The definition of the display is slightly degraded, with an observable graininess.It does indeed provide protection for the screen.An unexpected bonus was glare/shine elimination.  Nice.The touch sensitivity of the screen is likewise degraded.  The experience improves once one adapts to the slightly less sensitive touch (until then, you'll be doing some double-takes).Good product.  Not quite ideal, but it has it's uses and becomes less noticable as the user adapts.

reviewText: This screen works great and really blocks any one looking from the side view. Those close to you on the jammed in bus, subway and plane seats.
